articles.headline: Howard H. Baker Jr., ‘Great Conciliator’ of the Senate, Dies at 88
articles.snippet: Mr. Baker, the Senate Republican leader for eight years, was a forceful figure on the chamber’s Watergate committee and helped President Ronald Reagan weather the Iran-Contra scandal.
articles.abstract: Mr. Baker, the Senate Republican leader for eight years, was a forceful figure on the chamber’s Watergate committee and helped President Ronald Reagan weather the Iran-Contra scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Howard H. Baker Jr., a soft-spoken Tennessee lawyer who served three terms in the Senate and became known as “the great conciliator” in his eight years as the chamber’s Republican leader, died on Thursday at his home in Huntsville, Tenn. He was 88.

articles.headline: Corinthian Colleges Faltering as Flow of Federal Money Slows
articles.snippet: Once riding high with billions of dollars in federal loans to finance students for its schools, Corinthian is now close to collapse.
articles.abstract: Once riding high with billions of dollars in federal loans to finance students for its schools, Corinthian is now close to collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Corinthian Colleges was a Wall Street darling — a company that seemed to be able to coin money from the federal government and from desperate students. Now it is on the brink of collapse.

articles.headline: Forced to Hand Over Data, Facebook Files Appeal
articles.snippet: The New York district attorney’s office demanded account details of 381 people for an investigation that led to indictments on Social Security fraud charges.
articles.abstract: The New York district attorney’s office demanded account details of 381 people for an investigation that led to indictments on Social Security fraud charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorney’s office are in a bitter fight over the government’s demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and James C. McKinley Jr

articles.headline: In Prisons, Sky-High Phone Rates and Money Transfer Fees
articles.snippet: The jails and prisons get commissions from phone and financial companies, which then charge very high rates to inmates who have no other choices.
articles.abstract: The jails and prisons get commissions from phone and financial companies, which then charge very high rates to inmates who have no other choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the razor wire on Eagle Crest Way, in rural Clallam Bay, Wash., telephone calls start at $3.15. Emails out, beyond the security fence, run 33 cents. Money transfers in, to what pass for bank accounts, cost $4.95.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: The War to End All Wars? Hardly. But It Did Change Them Forever.
articles.snippet: World War I destroyed kings, kaisers, czars and sultans; it demolished empires; it introduced chemical weapons; it brought millions of women into the work force.
articles.abstract: World War I destroyed kings, kaisers, czars and sultans; it demolished empires; it introduced chemical weapons; it brought millions of women into the work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZONNEBEKE, Belgium — To walk the orderly rows of headstones in the elegant graveyards that hold the dead of World War I is to feel both awe and distance. With the death of the last veterans, World War I, which began 100 years ago, has moved from memory to history. But its resonance has not faded — on land and geography, people and nations, and on the causes and consequences of modern war.

articles.headline: Redrawn Lines Seen as No Cure in Iraq Conflict
articles.snippet: Fragmentation appears inevitable, but the tensions that divide may fuel new conflicts over ideology and natural resources.
articles.abstract: Fragmentation appears inevitable, but the tensions that divide may fuel new conflicts over ideology and natural resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Over the past two weeks, the specter that has haunted Iraq since its founding 93 years ago appears to have become a reality: the de facto partition of the country into Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish cantons.

articles.headline: The Road to Dov Charney’s Ouster at American Apparel
articles.snippet: The plan to fire American Apparel’s founder and chief executive took shape in a private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan.
articles.abstract: The plan to fire American Apparel’s founder and chief executive took shape in a private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a dimly lit private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan, four board members of American Apparel and their lawyer plotted out their next 24 hours over steaks and red wine.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: BNP Paribas Expected to Plead Guilty and Pay $8.9 Billion Fine
articles.snippet: New York has promised not to pull the bank’s license, but certain parts of its business will be suspended.
articles.abstract: New York has promised not to pull the bank’s license, but certain parts of its business will be suspended.
articles.lead_paragraph: BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, according to people briefed on the case. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Parts Supplier Delphi Is Scrutinized in G.M. Recall
articles.snippet: Senate investigators are widening the scope of the inquiry into General Motors’ decade-long failure to recall cars with a defective ignition switch to also focus on the supplier that made the flawed part.
articles.abstract: Senate investigators are widening the scope of the inquiry into General Motors’ decade-long failure to recall cars with a defective ignition switch to also focus on the supplier that made the flawed part.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senate investigators are widening the scope of the inquiry into General Motors’ decade-long failure to recall cars with a defective ignition switch to also focus on the supplier that made the flawed part.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Detroit Needs Residents, but Sends Some Packing
articles.snippet: In a city that needs to keep its residents, there is a virtual pipeline out, with more than one in 10 homes subject to foreclosure because of back property taxes.
articles.abstract: In a city that needs to keep its residents, there is a virtual pipeline out, with more than one in 10 homes subject to foreclosure because of back property taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ronald Ford Jr. has watched neighbors move away and brick houses on his family’s block crumble to nothing, but he says he wants to stay put and give a chance to city leaders who now promise a renaissance. “I’d like to try to go with the new Detroit if that’s really coming,” Mr. Ford, 49, said, standing outside the house on the city’s east side that he describes as precious, “like a family heirloom.”

articles.headline: Defying Russia, Ukraine Signs E.U. Trade Pact
articles.snippet: Moscow warned that the signing of the economic agreement, which had set off protests and fighting in Ukraine, would have “serious consequences.”
articles.abstract: Moscow warned that the signing of the economic agreement, which had set off protests and fighting in Ukraine, would have “serious consequences.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Dealing a defiant blow to the Kremlin, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine signed a long-delayed trade pact with Europe on Friday that Moscow had bitterly opposed. He then declared he would like his country to one day become a full member of the European Union.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Among Gay C.E.O.s, the Pressure to Conform
articles.snippet: John Browne, the former chief of BP, resigned in 2007 after published revelations about a gay lover. Seven years later, there are no publicly gay chief executives at any Fortune 500 company.
articles.abstract: John Browne, the former chief of BP, resigned in 2007 after published revelations about a gay lover. Seven years later, there are no publicly gay chief executives at any Fortune 500 company.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2007, John Browne, Lord Browne of Madingley, resigned as chief executive of the British oil giant BP after being outed as gay by the tabloid The Mail on Sunday: “The True story about Lord Browne — by ex-rent boy lover.”

articles.headline: A Nudge to Save a Bit More
articles.snippet: Some financial firms are providing online tools to help customers see what their peers are saving for retirement, in the hope of stepping up their game.
articles.abstract: Some financial firms are providing online tools to help customers see what their peers are saving for retirement, in the hope of stepping up their game.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re an active participant in social media, it’s nearly impossible to avoid a running tally of everyone else’s spending. New cars and home renovations are all over Facebook. Vacation photos, exotic meals and charity benefits are a fixture on Instagram.
